properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: One more warm night... Overnight minimums will remain near or above 13C tonight. By Wednesday afternoon an increasing flow of marine air will cause daytime temperatures to be slightly below 28C. The Heat Warning may be ended on Wednesday. ### To get more information: - Check the local news for health and safety updates. - Check HealthLinkBC online resources about heat-related illness and how to protect yourself at www.healthlinkbc.ca/healthlinkbc-files/heat-related-illness. - Call HealthLinkBC at 8-1-1 to ask about heat-related illness. Environment Canada and local Medical Health Officers expect an increase in health and safety risks from heat and are advising the public to take precautions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-07T15:32:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-06T23:33:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2901683557.2019
Area: Central Coast - inland sections, North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect

Description: Thunderstorms with wind gusts of 40 knots are possible this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first heat event of the summer is affecting the Fraser Canyon. A ridge of high pressure originating from the desert U.S. will remain over B.C. through Thursday. This will produce daytime maximums above 36C while overnight lows remain near or above 18C. Slightly cooler air will arrive beginning on Friday. ### To get more information: - Check the local news for health and safety updates. - Check HealthLinkBC online resources about heat-related illness and how to protect yourself at www.healthlinkbc.ca/healthlinkbc-files/heat-related-illness. - Call HealthLinkBC at 8-1-1 to ask about heat-related illness. Environment Canada and local Medical Health Officers expect an increase in health and safety risks from heat and are advising the public to take precautions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-07T15:54:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-06T23:55:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3950788328.2019
Area: Fraser Canyon - north including Lillooet, Fraser Canyon - south including Lytton
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: South Okanagan, including Penticton, Summerland, Naramata, Keremeos, Oliver and Osoyoos, will be impacted by wildfire smoke over the next 24-48 hours. During a wildfire, smoke conditions can change quickly over short distances and can vary considerably hour-by-hour. Wildfire smoke is a natural part of our environment but it is important to be mindful that exposure to smoke may affect your health. People with pre-existing health conditions, the elderly, pregnant women and infants, children, and sensitive individuals are more likely to experience health effects from smoke exposure. The bulletin can be accessed online at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/ air/air-quality/air-advisories. The next bulletin update will be available August 07, 2019. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-07T15:12:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-08-06T23:13:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1002219099.2019
Area: South Okanagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot Spell for the Southern Interior through Thursday... A ridge of high pressure originating from the desert U.S. has set up shop over the BC interior and will stick around for a few days. It will produce the first spell of hot weather so far this summer. At this time we don't expect to issue a widespread Heat Warning for the southern interior. However, the public is encouraged to protect themselves from the heat. - Drink plenty of water even before you feel thirsty and stay in a cool place. - Schedule outdoor activities during the coolest parts of the day. - Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. Communities will see daytime highs soar into mid-30s while overnight lows recover to the low to mid-teens. Environment and Climate Change Canada's criteria for issuing a Heat Warning requires maximum temperatures greater 35C and overnight lows greater than 18C for two or more consecutive days. Many locales will reach or exceed the 35C high temperature threshold but most areas will drop below 18C at night. A reprieve from the heat will begin on Friday. The transition to more seasonal temperatures will be accompanied by thunderstorms. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-07T07:13:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-06T23:14:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2109943648.2019
Area: South Thompson, Nicola, Similkameen, North Okanagan - including Vernon, Central Okanagan - including Kelowna, South Okanagan - including Penticton, Arrow Lakes - Slocan Lake, Boundary, West Kootenay, Kootenay Lake, North Thompson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Thunderstorms are forming in Northwestern Ontario and Southern Manitoba near the international border. Some of these thunderstorms may become severe with the threats of nickel size hail and wind gusts to 90 km/h. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-08-07T10:08:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-06T22:09:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3641927024.2019
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Ear Falls - Perrault Falls - Western Lac Seul, Sioux Lookout - Eastern Lac Seul, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson, Dryden - Vermilion Bay, Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 8:19 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. A line of severe thunderstorms located from Migisi Sahgaigan to 30 km east of Dryden is moving southeastward at 70 km/h along Highway 17. This line of storms has a history of producing wind gusts up to 100 km/h. Communities in the path include: Aaron Provincial Park, Wabigoon, Dinorwic, Wabigoon Lake Ojibway, Borups Corners and Dyment. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-08-07T03:39:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-07T01:20:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3144080318.2019
Area: Dryden - Vermilion Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Thunderstorms are expected to continue to develop this afternoon and last into the evening. Some of these thunderstorms may become severe. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
